"I determined to punch off the
head of this thing called war," said
Mr. Everett Colby in his talk to
the Assembly last Thursday. Mr.
Colby explained the innermost
workings of the Leaglie of Nations and World Court. He said
that ever since he saw the horrible sights of the great war he .has
been determined to do all in his
power toward putting a stop to
such world upheavals.
Mr. Colby, a well-known lawyer
of New York, is noted for his political activities in connection with
the Non-partisan League of Nations Association. Last summer
he went to Geneva "to see how the
League of Nations was working."
His first shock was the sight of the
flags in the front of his hotel, representing every country of the
world with the exception of Germany, Russia, Turkey, Mexico, an
African tribe and the United
States. "That's the group we're
in," he said.

Pennsylvania has offered to employ twelve men during the coming summer vacation who have successfully completed the junior year

chemical engineering. The period
of training will be for thirteen
weeks.

For seven years the United States Naval Academy's lacrosse
team stood supreme and undefeated. Last Saturday, in Washington, the unforeseen happened, the great, unconquerable twelve bowed
to the University of Maryland. Students at Hopkins were unanimous
in declaring that they were glad to see Navy lose, but that they were
sorry to see Maryland win. The result of that game, however; is a
good thing for our University. It means that larger crowds than ever
before will flock to Homewood Field to witness the Hopkins-Navy
contest and the Hopkins-Maryland game the following week. On
both occasions, Hopkins must show her best. We feel confident that
the team will give all they have. It remains for the student body to
fill the cheering section and show their support. Last Saturday, an
official count showed ninety-seven men in the cheering squad out of
a student body of six hundred and thirty-five and eleven men and a
leader in the Band out of a membership of forty-four. If we are to
beat Navy, we must have one hundred per cent. attendance.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 16, 1924
INCREASE IN POPULATION A
MENACE, SAYS DR.
PEARL
That the world has already
passed its period of greatest growth
in population and that a continued
increase in population would cause
a lowering of living standards was
aptly illustrated in an intensely interesting lecture delivered last
Thursday in the C. E. Hall by Dr.
Raymond Pearl, professor of statistics at the Johns Hopkins Medical School. "The Population Problem," the subject of the address,
was declared by the speaker to be
a biological problem of growth. Interest in this problem invariably increases after great wars, Dr. Pearl
stated.

The critic who charges college men with lack
of diligence never heard a freshman repeat his roll
of fraternity chapters without a slip, or a senior
dilate on the life history of every football captain
from 1890 on.
Ofcourse this takes study—sometimestoo much
study. The student must be cautioned against
the mental strain resulting from concentration on
too limited a field of thought.
It is a good thing to specialize, but not to the
extent of becoming narrow. If it is right for the
man who concentrates on engineering to be up
on his campus activities, it would seem right for
the man who is quoted on the history and philosophy of Comparative Baseball Scores to have
some knowledge of the chemistry and thermodynamicsfrom which he expects to make his living.
For it is still true that in industrial councils the
talk sometimes swings from batting averages to
coefficients of expansion and the hysteresis losses
in iron.
This is all a matter of balance, and satisfactory
mental balance is a means to an important end—
satisfactory bank balance.

current that went through Alfriend," Professor Kowenhaven

than that and still remained physically fit. But, had the current been
of the high amperage, low frequency kind that is retailed by the Consolidated Gas and Electric, he no
doubt would have suffered considerable damage."
Alfriend, in spite of the accident, was able to demonstrate his
experiment at the Engineering

"I determined to punch off the
head of this thing called war," said
Mr. Everett Colby in his talk to
the Assembly last Thursday. Mr.
Colby explained the innermost
workings of the Leaglie of Nations and World Court. He said
that ever since he saw the horrible sights of the great war he .has
been determined to do all in his
power toward putting a stop to
such world upheavals.
Mr. Colby, a well-known lawyer
of New York, is noted for his political activities in connection with
the Non-partisan League of Nations Association. Last summer
he went to Geneva "to see how the
League of Nations was working."
His first shock was the sight of the
flags in the front of his hotel, representing every country of the
world with the exception of Germany, Russia, Turkey, Mexico, an
African tribe and the United
States. "That's the group we're
in," he said.

For seven years the United States Naval Academy's lacrosse
team stood supreme and undefeated. Last Saturday, in Washington, the unforeseen happened, the great, unconquerable twelve bowed
to the University of Maryland. Students at Hopkins were unanimous
in declaring that they were glad to see Navy lose, but that they were
sorry to see Maryland win. The result of that game, however; is a
good thing for our University. It means that larger crowds than ever
before will flock to Homewood Field to witness the Hopkins-Navy
contest and the Hopkins-Maryland game the following week. On
both occasions, Hopkins must show her best. We feel confident that
the team will give all they have. It remains for the student body to
fill the cheering section and show their support. Last Saturday, an
official count showed ninety-seven men in the cheering squad out of
a student body of six hundred and thirty-five and eleven men and a
leader in the Band out of a membership of forty-four. If we are to
beat Navy, we must have one hundred per cent. attendance.

That the world has already
passed its period of greatest growth
in population and that a continued
increase in population would cause
a lowering of living standards was
aptly illustrated in an intensely interesting lecture delivered last
Thursday in the C. E. Hall by Dr.
Raymond Pearl, professor of statistics at the Johns Hopkins Medical School. "The Population Problem," the subject of the address,
was declared by the speaker to be
a biological problem of growth. Interest in this problem invariably increases after great wars, Dr. Pearl
stated.

The critic who charges college men with lack
of diligence never heard a freshman repeat his roll
of fraternity chapters without a slip, or a senior
dilate on the life history of every football captain
from 1890 on.
Ofcourse this takes study—sometimestoo much
study. The student must be cautioned against
the mental strain resulting from concentration on
too limited a field of thought.
It is a good thing to specialize, but not to the
extent of becoming narrow. If it is right for the
man who concentrates on engineering to be up
on his campus activities, it would seem right for
the man who is quoted on the history and philosophy of Comparative Baseball Scores to have
some knowledge of the chemistry and thermodynamicsfrom which he expects to make his living.
For it is still true that in industrial councils the
talk sometimes swings from batting averages to
coefficients of expansion and the hysteresis losses
in iron.
This is all a matter of balance, and satisfactory
mental balance is a means to an important end—
satisfactory bank balance.

Alfriend across the Styx, said, "It
isn't the volt, its the amperes. The
current that went through Alfriend," Professor Kowenhaven
continued, "was of very high frequency. He could have taken more
than that and still remained physically fit. But, had the current been
of the high amperage, low frequency kind that is retailed by the Consolidated Gas and Electric, he no
doubt would have suffered considerable damage."
Alfriend, in spite of the accident, was able to demonstrate his
experiment at the Engineering
Show last Friday and Saturday.
